**Cleaver** is an [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. Its [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") is a [battle-axe](/wiki/Battle-axe "Battle-axe"), and it is [neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral")-aligned. It is the guaranteed first [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift") for [Barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian").

[ ]

## Description

Cleaver has a [+d3](/wiki/D_notation "D notation") [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") bonus and does an extra +d6 damage per hit. Uniquely, it can hit multiple monsters in an arc with one swing: each attack will first strike the monster 45 degrees to one side of your target, then the targeted monster, and then the monster 45 degrees to the other side. The direction of attack alternates with each swing.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) The arc **does not** discriminate between hostile monsters and [pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet") or [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful") monsters. If attacking while held or engulfed, you can only hit the monster holding or engulfing you.

Like other [axes](/wiki/Axe "Axe"), [applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") Cleaver in a given direction can chop down [trees](/wiki/Trees "Trees") and destroy [doors](/wiki/Door "Door").

## Strategy

Cleaver's arc attack potentially makes it one of the most damaging weapons in the game by a pure damage-per-turn calculation. Moreover, it is most effective in "one vs. many" scenarios, which are also the most dangerous situations for a player to find themselves in. Cleaver's arced strikes can help you in these situations by opening gaps to flee through or to reposition yourself in.

Because your pets are just as much endangered by Cleaver's attack as hostile monsters, it may be prohibitively difficult to keep them around. A [magic whistle](/wiki/Magic_whistle "Magic whistle") can help orient them "properly" before you attack, as can blocking them off using doors or cursed items if you are aware of the potential for combat beforehand. Slower pets such as [dragons](/wiki/Dragon "Dragon") and [balrogs](/wiki/Balrog "Balrog") are easier to work with, as you can move a few steps away before attacking.

For the same reason, this weapon is also extremely dangerous to wield in peaceful-populated areas such as the [Quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest"), [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown"), [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop"), and [temples](/wiki/Temple "Temple") - it is particularly advisable to use a different weapon while [altar](/wiki/Altar "Altar")-scumming with a co-[aligned priest](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest") in the room. In general, combat with Cleaver proves far easier if you can lure your foes away from peaceful targets.

As a two-handed non-[intelligent artifact](/wiki/Intelligent_artifact "Intelligent artifact") weapon, Cleaver risks being welded to your hands if it becomes cursed. The usual strategies for two-handed weapons apply: make sure to keep some keep curse removal items on hand, including carrying [holy water](/wiki/Holy_water "Holy water") in a spare sack to #[tip](/wiki/Tip "Tip") out if necessary.

## History

Cleaver's striking arc is introduced in [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1"), and was adapted from [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack").

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

Like all artifacts with damage bonuses (as opposed to double damage), Cleaver receives a boost in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"); it always gives +3 to hit and +6 damage. However, the above strategies regarding two-handed weapons still apply, especially given the proliferation of item-cursing spellcasters in SLASH'EM—[ghoul mages](/wiki/Ghoul_mage "Ghoul mage"), [nabassus](/wiki/Nabassu "Nabassu"), [vampire mages](/wiki/Vampire_mage "Vampire mage"), [devas](/wiki/Deva "Deva"), and the like. Since SLASH'EM is based on NetHack 3.4.3, Cleaver does not attack monsters in an arc.

However, note that non-human Barbarians have a second guaranteed sacrifice gift in SLASH'EM: [Deathsword](/wiki/Deathsword "Deathsword"). This weapon is only particularly effective against humans; for that reason, it mostly gets in the way of getting a better weapon, and some barbarians may find themselves using Cleaver for longer than they might want.

Given that 1⁄3 of neutral sacrifice gifts are non-weapons ([Deluder](/wiki/Deluder "Deluder"), [Gauntlets of Defense](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_Defense "Gauntlets of Defense"), [Mirrorbright](/wiki/Mirrorbright "Mirrorbright"), and [Whisperfeet](/wiki/Whisperfeet "Whisperfeet")) and another 1⁄4 are of limited use ([Disrupter](/wiki/Disrupter "Disrupter") vs. non-undead, [Giantkiller](/wiki/Giantkiller "Giantkiller") vs. non-giants, and [Sword of Balance](/wiki/Sword_of_Balance "Sword of Balance") vs. neutrals), a neutral player who receives Cleaver early should consider himself lucky; only [Magicbane](/wiki/Magicbane "Magicbane") and [Mjollnir](/wiki/Mjollnir "Mjollnir") are more powerful as general-use neutral weapons, particularly in the early and midgame where curses are not a significant threat.

### UnNetHack

Cleaver in [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack") behaves as in 3.6.1, and is also easier to obtain. The [Executioner](/wiki/Executioner "Executioner") is guaranteed to be generated with Cleaver if it has not yet appeared in-game

### FIQHack

In [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack"), Cleaver has the ability to hit multiple foes, and the behavior was adapted for vanilla; however, it will not hit pets or peacefuls unless they are directly targeted.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), the arc will not strike peaceful monsters unless you do so intentionally by force-fighting with [F](/wiki/F "F").

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), Cleaver will not hit peaceful monsters in its arc unless cursed.

Cleaver can be combined with [Mjollnir](/wiki/Mjollnir "Mjollnir") at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") to create [Tempest](/wiki/Tempest "Tempest"), an artifact [halberd](/wiki/Halberd "Halberd").

## Encyclopedia entry

Hither came Conan, the Cimmerian, black-haired, sullen-eyed,  
sword in hand, a thief, a reaver, a slayer, with gigantic  
melancholies and gigantic mirth, to tread the jeweled  
thrones of the Earth under his sandalled feet.

\[ The Phoenix on the Sword, by Robert E. Howard ]
